propositions.text: The story is set at a house called 'Crow's Nest' owned by Sir Charles Cartwright.
Mr. Saddlethwaite is observing Sir Charles Cartwright climbing up to the house.
Crow's Nest is described as a modern, well-built bungalow with a good location overlooking 'Lynton Harbour'.
Sir Charles Cartwright is a middle-aged man, portrayed as an actor who is always 'acting' even in his personal life.
Sir Charles has retired from the stage to live a simple country life by the sea.
This retirement is viewed by others as a role he is playing.
Mr. Saddlethwaite is a patron of arts and theatre, and a keen observer of people.
Dr. Bartholomew Strange, a psychiatrist and Sir Charles' friend, arrives and joins Mr. Saddlethwaite.
Dr. Strange also believes Sir Charles is playing a role and will eventually tire of his current 'simple country life'.
Sir Charles Cartwright arrives and is greeted by Mr. Saddlethwaite and Dr. Strange.
Sir Charles mentions 'Mirabelle' defeating herself and invites Dr. Strange to join them.
Mr. Saddlethwaite dislikes sea travel due to seasickness.
Sir Charles asks for a drink and invites Dr. Strange to join their 'crew'.
Dr. Strange remarks on the advantage of being a doctor: not having to follow one's own advice.
Sir Charles is described as a gentleman and an actor.
Sir Charles reveals he has a helper named 'Cynthia'.
Mr. Saddlethwaite inquires about Cynthia Lytton-Gore, who knows a little about sailing.
Sir Charles admits Cynthia made him feel like a fool but helped him.
Mr. Saddlethwaite speculates that Cynthia might be the reason for Sir Charles' continued satisfaction, linking it to men of his age often having younger female companions.
Sir Charles expresses his love for the sea, sun, wind, and a simple cottage.
His 'simple cottage' is revealed to be a well-equipped house with modern amenities.
Miss Milray, described as unattractive, emerges from the house and presents a dinner menu.
Miss Milray asks to join dinner to avoid a table of thirteen, due to superstition.
She is highly efficient and manages the household like clockwork.
Sir Charles mentions she was his secretary in London and is now his housekeeper, but she is leaving.
Sir Charles is unsure of her reason for leaving, suspecting it's not her stated reason of a disabled mother.
Dr. Strange suggests people talk about Miss Milray.
Sir Charles is surprised and dismisses the idea of gossip involving him and Miss Milray, based on her appearance and age.
Sir Charles describes Miss Milray as dignified, chaste, and extremely capable.
The guests for the afternoon are listed.
Angela Sacliffe, a famous actress.
The Dykes family: Mrs. Dykes, a dressmaker, and Captain Dykes, a racehorse owner.
The playwright Anthony Astor (later identified as a woman named Miss Wells).
The Babington family: a clergyman and his wife.
Mrs. Mary and Cynthia Lytton-Gore.
A young traveler named Mr. Manders.
Mr. Saddlethwaite counts the guests and realizes there is a discrepancy in the numbers mentioned.
Sir Charles realizes he forgot one guest: Mr. Poirot.
Mr. Poirot is described as an outstanding, albeit self-important, Belgian detective.
Dr. Strange discusses the nature of eventful lives versus uneventful lives, suggesting cases find people rather than the other way around.
He uses Poirot as an example of someone cases are drawn to.
Sir Charles jokingly suggests he won't be the victim.
The first chapter ends with the three men entering the house.
Chapter 2 begins with Mr. Saddlethwaite's primary interest in people, particularly women.
He feels like an observer rather than a participant in life.
Mr. Saddlethwaite observes Mrs. Cynthia Dykes, noting her fashionable appearance and the artificiality of her beauty.
Mrs. Dykes uses the fashionable term 'permeates' in her speech.
Sir Charles is seen chatting with Angela Sacliffe.
Captain Dykes discusses horse racing with Dr. Strange.
Miss Wells (Anthony Astor) is introduced as a tall, slender playwright known for her witty and impactful work.
She expresses her dislike for the South of France, despite finding it beneficial for her writing.
Mr. Saddlethwaite is surprised by the contrast between her witty writing and her personal demeanor.
Miss Wells' observant eyes make Mr. Saddlethwaite uneasy.
Mr. Saddlethwaite offers to get Miss Wells a drink, but she offers to make one for him.
Mrs. Mary Lytton-Gore and her daughter, Miss Lytton-Gore (Cynthia), arrive.
Mrs. Lytton-Gore is a widow with a young daughter.
Cynthia (Egg-Egg) is described as lively and charming, though not conventionally beautiful.
She is full of youthful energy and has a vibrant presence.
Cynthia is talking to Oliver Manders, a handsome young man with a foreign air.
Hercule Poirot is also present, observing Oliver Manders with amusement, though appearing somewhat sad.
Reverend Stephen Babington expresses his appreciation for Sir Charles.
Mrs. Babington agrees, noting Sir Charles' childlike nature.
Cynthia offers cocktails to the ladies.
Mrs. Babington discusses gardening with Sir Charles.
Mrs. Mary Lytton-Gore asks about the young woman in green, who turns out to be the playwright Anthony Astor (Miss Wells).
Mrs. Lytton-Gore is surprised by Miss Wells' appearance, finding her unlike what she expected.
Reverend Babington drinks a cocktail and begins to show signs of distress.
He clutches his throat and collapses.
Cynthia screams, announcing that Mr. Babington has fallen ill.
Dr. Strange tries to help but confirms that Reverend Babington is dead.
Chapter 3 begins with Sir Charles calling Mr. Saddlethwaite into the 'cabin hall' after the commotion.
Calm has returned after the death of Reverend Babington.
Mrs. Babington has been taken away, and the local doctor has been called.
Mr. Saddlethwaite is visibly shaken by witnessing a death.
Dr. Strange and Sir Charles are also present.
Dr. Strange compliments Mr. Saddlethwaite's ability to 'understand life'.
Sir Charles is distressed by the event.
Sir Charles asks Dr. Strange if he has seen someone die like this before.
Dr. Strange states he hasn't seen many deaths as a psychiatrist focused on keeping patients alive.
He contrasts this with Dr. McDougal, the local physician, who has likely seen more deaths.
Dr. McDougal concluded that the death was due to a sudden illness, but Dr. Strange is not satisfied with this explanation.
He acknowledges that doctors often use vague explanations like 'sudden illness' to satisfy laypeople.
Dr. Strange notes that Reverend Babington was elderly and had been unwell.
Sir Charles hints at suspicion, leading to a discussion about the possibility of suicide or murder.
Dr. Strange dismisses the idea of murder, deeming it unthinkable to murder a harmless old clergyman.
He suggests suicide as a possibility, speculating about motives like a terminal illness.
Sir Charles is hesitant to accept suicide and mentions he mixed the cocktails.
Dr. Strange lightheartedly suggests the possibility of poison.
Dr. Strange admonishes Sir Charles for his speculative and potentially harmful insinuations, which could cause distress to Mrs. Babington.
He emphasizes that baseless speculation can lead to damaging rumors.
Sir Charles insists he has a 'premonition' that something is not right.
Mr. Saddlethwaite shares his observation that Reverend Babington looked pained after drinking his cocktail, initially attributing it to him not being accustomed to the taste.
He suggests that Reverend Babington might have put something in his own glass.
Mr. Saddlethwaite proposes that Dr. Strange discreetly examine the cocktail glass.
Dr. Strange agrees to examine the glass but bets there will be nothing in it but gin and vermouth.
Sir Charles blames Dr. Strange's earlier discussion about Poirot for his own suspicions of murder.
Hercule Poirot appears, and Sir Charles directly asks for his opinion on whether something is amiss.
Poirot notes the suddenness of Reverend Babington's illness.
Mr. Saddlethwaite explains his thoughts on suicide and the suggestion to examine the cocktail glass.
Poirot agrees to examine the glass, finding suicide unlikely given Reverend Babington's character and the social setting.
He suspects the glass will only contain cocktail ingredients, as poisoning in such a setting would be technically difficult.
Poirot leaves without a trace.
Chapter 4 begins with Cynthia Lytton-Gore confronting Mr. Saddlethwaite, insisting he share his true thoughts.
She dismisses the idea that Reverend Babington's death was due to natural causes, citing his health history.
Cynthia questions the thoroughness of Dr. McDougal's examination and Dr. Strange's cautious opinion.
Mr. Saddlethwaite reminds her that the cocktail glass was found to contain only gin and vermouth.
Cynthia mentions that Dr. Strange said something to Oliver Manders after the examination.
She describes Oliver Manders as ambitious and restless, wanting to become a journalist.
Cynthia expresses her grief over Reverend Babington's death, whom she respected.
She claims to be a genuine Christian, unlike her mother.
She discusses the Babington family's piety and mentions their son Robin, who was killed in India and whom she was once infatuated with.
Cynthia insists that if Reverend Babington did not die naturally, it's a terrible misfortune.
She suggests the possibility of someone using a needle or a poisoned dart.
Cynthia reveals that she and Charles (Sir Charles) suspect foul play.
Mr. Saddlethwaite recalls a poem from 'The Quotations Dictionary' about an older man and a younger woman, making a connection to Sir Charles and Cynthia.

concepts.name: Mr. Saddlethwaite
concepts.context: The main observer and narrator of events, interested in people.

concepts.name: Sir Charles Cartwright
concepts.context: Owner of Crow's Nest, former actor, now living by the sea, suspects foul play.

concepts.name: Dr. Bartholomew Strange
concepts.context: Psychiatrist, friend of Sir Charles, offers professional opinions and explanations.

concepts.name: Cynthia Lytton-Gore
concepts.context: Young woman, companion to her mother, lively and energetic, suspects foul play with Sir Charles.

concepts.name: Reverend Stephen Babington
concepts.context: Clergyman who dies suddenly at the dinner party.

concepts.name: Miss Milray
concepts.context: Sir Charles' efficient housekeeper, described as unattractive.

concepts.name: Hercule Poirot
concepts.context: Famous detective, present at the gathering, consulted on the death.

concepts.name: Crow's Nest
concepts.context: Sir Charles Cartwright's house.

concepts.name: Cocktail
concepts.context: The drink consumed by Reverend Babington before his death, a focus of suspicion.

concepts.name: Death
concepts.context: The central event of the latter part of the narrative.

concepts.name: Acting/Role-playing
concepts.context: A recurring theme, especially related to Sir Charles' personality.

concepts.name: Observation
concepts.context: Mr. Saddlethwaite's primary method of engaging with the story.

concepts.name: Suspicion
concepts.context: The underlying tone regarding the death of Reverend Babington.

concepts.name: Mrs. Mary Lytton-Gore
concepts.context: Cynthia's mother, a widow.

concepts.name: Oliver Manders
concepts.context: A young traveler, potentially ambitious and restless.

concepts.name: Angela Sacliffe
concepts.context: A famous actress, guest at the party.

concepts.name: Anthony Astor (Miss Wells)
concepts.context: A playwright, guest at the party.

concepts.name: Captain Dykes
concepts.context: Husband of Mrs. Dykes, involved in horse racing.

concepts.name: Mrs. Dykes
concepts.context: Dressmaker, wife of Captain Dykes.

concepts.name: Dr. McDougal
concepts.context: Local physician who examined Reverend Babington.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into four chapters, progressing from the introduction of characters and setting to the central mystery of a suspicious death and the initial stages of investigation.
